First of all, they are sometimes not taught well in schools. It takes time to develop these skills in students and enough time is something that most teachers do not have because of large classes, strict scheduling, and academic deadlines. Secondly, some people do not relate what they learn in an academic setting to real life applications, they simply leave it behind in the classroom. Thirdly, stimulation overload numbs the brain; today, under constant barrage from the output of our personal devices, people have learned not to spend too much time thinking about anything in particular, which would exercise critical thinking skills, but find their mental processes dominated by repetitive limited attention to many different things. Fourthly, social trends and pressures direct people away from critical thinking - it’s easier and more popular to trash something than it is to reason about it. The rise of internet trolls and the language of prominent modern politicians clearly demonstrate this. And fifth, a culture driven by the importance of self over all else negates attempts to introduce critical thinking - if I believe I’m right about something then the belief that my opinion is just as good as yours means that whatever argument you present, I’m not listening to you, even if I haven’t done any work to substantiate my opinion. I think that critical thinkers tend to be marginalized by much of the population because their language, search for insight, and attention to detail make them outsiders in modern popular culture.
